? 68.155 Executive summary.
The owner or operator shall provide in the RMP an executive summary that includes a brief description of the following elements:
(a) The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source;
(b) The stationary source and regulated substances handled;
(c) The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps;
(d) The five-year accident history; 
(e) The emergency response program; and
(f) Planned changes to improve safety.

Glo-Tex and Regulated Substances (40 CFR 68.155(b)
Glo-Tex is located on a 14-acre tract north of Spartanburg, South Carolina (Spartanburg County).  Glo-Tex produces acrylic polymers in both emulsion polymerization and solvent-based reactions.  This utilizes a number of chemicals as raw materials, six of which are listed as toxic materials in 40 CFR 68.130.  Of these four chemicals, two of them are planned to be on site in quantities that exceed the threshold planning quantity, acrylonitrile and vinyl acetate.  The other four chemicals, formaldehyde, ammonia, epichlorohydrin and hydrochloric acid greater than 37%, are kept in quantities below the threshold planning quantities.

Acrylonitrile
At Glo-Tex, acrylonitrile is handled and stored as a non-refrigerated liquid.  Effects of acute exposure to high concentrations of acrylonitrile include irritation of the respiratory tract experienced as nasal discomfort and discharge, with chest pain, coughing, headache, nausea, vomiting, dizziness, and drowsiness.  At high doses acrylonitrile can be fatal by inhalation, ingestion, skin contact and other routes.  The threshold quantity listed in 40 CFR 68.130 for acrylonitrile is 20,000 lb.  Glo-Tex uses acrylonitrile as a raw material in polymerization reactions and stores a maximum of 10,000 gallons (66,753 pounds) in its monomer tank farm. 

Glo-Tex had an accident involving a reportable quantity of this material on July 21, 2006.

Vinyl Acetate Monomer
Vinyl a

cetate is also handled and stored as a non-refrigerated liquid.  Effects of acute exposure to high concentrations of vinyl acetate monomer include irritation of the respiratory tract experienced as nasal discomfort and discharge, with chest pain, coughing, headache, nausea, vomiting, dizziness, and drowsiness.  Liquid or vapor may cause irritation of the eyes experienced as stinging, excess blinking and tear production, with excess redness in the conjunctiva.  At high doses vinyl acetate can be fatal by inhalation, ingestion, skin contact and other routes.  The RMP threshold quantity listed in 40 CFR 68.130 for vinyl acetate monomer is 15,000 lb.  Glo-Tex uses vinyl acetate as a raw material in polymerization reactions and stores a maximum of 15,000 gallons (116,590 pounds) in its monomer tank farm.

Glo-Tex had an accident involving a reportable quantity of this material on July 21, 2006.

Ammonia
Ammonia is also handled and stored as a non-refrigerated, aqueous liquid.  Effects of acute exposure to high concentrations of ammonia include eye, mucous membrane and systemic irritation by inhalation. .  At high doses ammonia can be fatal by inhalation, ingestion, and possibly other routes.  The threshold quantity for ammonia is 20,000 pounds [40 CFR 68.130].  Glo-Tex uses aqueous solutions of ammonia in many of its processes and stores a 26 ?Be (~29.5 wt%) aqueous ammonia in a 7,860 gallon vertical tank.  The aqueous ammonia has the following properties:

Aqua Ammonia ? Specifications(Ref: Industrial Resources Group http://www.indresgroup.com/aqua_safety.htm)
Ammonia Content/Assay     29.4% by weight
Density    26 ? Be
Specific Gravity     0.8974 @ 60 degrees F
Density    7.48 lb/gal

The maximum of ammonia stored at Glo-Tex is shown below:  
 
The maximum quantity stored is less than the threshold quantity of 20,000 pounds [40 CFR 68.130]; therefore, ammonia was not evaluated quantitatively.    

Glo-Tex has not had an accident or incident involving a reportable quantity of ammon

ia in the last five years.

 
Formaldehyde
Glo-Tex uses 37% formaldehyde solution in the production processes in small quantities, and the Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) for N-methylolacrylamide indicates that this monomer may contain a maximum of 2% formaldehyde by weight.  N-Methylolacrylamide is received and used in drums and tote tanks and the MSDS indicates that the specific gravity is 1.07 to 1.10.  The threshold quantity for formaldehyde is 15,000 pounds [40 CFR 68.130].  

Based upon the highest reported specific gravity for the N-methylolacrylamide mixture of 1.10 and the maximum formaldehyde concentration of 2%, the maximum quantity of formaldehyde stored with N-methylolacrylamide at Glo-Tex is shown below:   
 
The 37% (wt) formaldehyde solution has a specific gravity of 1.08 and is stored in drums or portable tote tanks.  Glo-Tex only has a few drums stored on site, but to exceed the threshold, they would have to store 3,900 gallons or more than 70 drums.  
 
The maximum quantity stored is less than the threshold amount of 15,000 pounds [40 CFR 68.130]; therefore, formaldehyde was not evaluated quantitatively.  

Glo-Tex has not had an accident or incident involving a reportable quantity of formaldehyde in the last five years.

Epichlorohydrin
Glo-Tex uses epichlorohydrin in the production processes in small quantities.  Epichlorohydrin is received and used in drums and tote tanks and the MSDS indicates that the specific gravity is 1.173.  The threshold quantity for epichlorohydrin is 20,000 pounds [40 CFR 68.130].  

The facility estimates that a maximum of four drums of epichlorohydrin are on-site at any point in time.  Therefore, the maximum quantity of epichlorohydrin stored at Glo-Tex is shown below:   

 
The maximum quantity stored is less than the threshold amount of 20,000 pounds [40 CFR 68.130]; therefore, epichlorohydrin was not evaluated quantitatively.  

Glo-Tex has not had an accident or incident involving a reportable quantity of epich

lorohydrin in the last five years.

Hydrochloric acid solution (37% or greater concentration)
Glo-Tex uses hydrochloric acid solution in the production processes in small quantities.  hydrochloric acid solution is received and used in drums and tote tanks and the hazardous substances database indicates that the specific gravity is 1.20 for a 39 % solution.  The threshold quantity for hydrochloric acid solution is 15,000 pounds [40 CFR 68.130].  

The facility estimates that a maximum of four drums of hydrochloric acid solution are on-site at any point in time.  Therefore, the maximum quantity of hydrochloric acid solution stored at Glo-Tex is shown below:   

 
The maximum quantity stored is less than the threshold amount of 15,000 pounds [40 CFR 68.130]; therefore, hydrochloric acid solution was not evaluated quantitatively.  

Glo-Tex has not had an accident or incident involving a reportable quantity of hydrochloric acid solution in the last five years.

Other Materials
Throughout its production processes, Glo-Tex uses additional monomers and solvents that are not listed under 40 CFR 68.130 and, therefore, not subject to RMP requirements.  

 
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response (40 CFR 68.155(a) and 68.155(c))
Glo-Tex has instituted policies and procedures to address accidental release prevention and emergency response including:

Operating Procedures
Glo-Tex is a certified ISO 9001 facility; therefore, Glo-Tex has ISO procedures for all of its manufacturing processes, including polymer manufacturing.  The ISO procedures are found on the Glo-Tex network.

Training
It is Glo-Tex?s training philosophy that all employees will be trained to perform their assigned duties safely and effectively.  To this end, a procedure was created to provide work instructions and training documentation tools for effectively and systematically planning training initiatives, assessing training needs, providing required employee training, and maintaining appropriate tr

aining records.  Glo-Tex uses both classroom and on-the-job training for employees.  To assess employee training needs, the supervisor requires employees to demonstrate competency in the material or observes the employees executing tasks new to them. Glo-Tex also uses some oral and written tests.  The training procedure is located in Section 21 of the Safety Manual.

Mechanical Integrity and Maintenance
In order to ensure an efficient workplace, preventive maintenance is performed on a majority of the equipment at Glo-Tex.  Maintenance procedures are included in the preventative maintenance schedules.  A preventative maintenance schedule has been developed for each piece of equipment at Glo-Tex and each month a list of required preventative maintenance activities is printed out and employees are notified of assigned tasks.  For preventative maintenance activities that require a greater frequency than once per month, a checklist is provided and these tasks are completed on the schedule stated.  An excel spreadsheet is used to develop the list of maintenance tasks for each piece of equipment.  The procedure for mechanical integrity is found in Section 22 of the Safety Manual.

Management of Change
The market for the polymers and gums that are made by Glo-Tex changes rapidly.  In many instances, products are tailored for specific applications and must be formulated and manufactured.  Glo-Tex?s R&D and Production Departments confer prior to manufacturing any new product.  A portion of the discussion concerns the potential for adverse impacts including releases, especially those that would produce odors.  Glo-Tex is sensitive to odors because the threshold of odor for the acrylate compounds is much lower than any concentration that would affect health.  Glo-Tex documents the discussions regarding new products in a batch sheet that outlines the steps in the manufacturing process.

Standard Operating Procedures are developed for each new product to provide the operators wi

th detailed instructions for each product made by Glo-Tex.  The R&D Department develops a process designed to safely scale the production up from 1-liter reactors up to full production sized units.  The Management of Change procedure creates a written record that addresses scale up issues for new products.    This procedure assures that the products can be safely made.

The potential for adverse effects due to changes to process equipment is also considered by reviewing revised P&IDs.  These evaluations are generally documented in a meeting record, memorandum, an ISO procedure, or some other appropriate form.

A management of change procedure has been developed to address the three types of changes that may occur at Glo-Tex.  These changes are:
?    Change in SOP or introduction of new SOP
?    Addition of new equipment
?    Reconfiguration of existing equipment

The management of change procedure can be found in Section 23 of the Safety Manual.

Pre-Startup Review
Prior to beginning production of any new product formulation, the product is made in bench scale sizes and usually in one or both of the pilot scale reactors in the Process Department.  This ensures to the extent possible that the product quality will meet the requirements and no adverse conditions will be created.  
For new equipment, a formal start up procedure is prepared with input from the Process Department, the designer, and the persons installing the equipment.  This procedure is reviewed with management prior to startup.

For new equipment, the purchase and installation of new equipment requires two steps.  The first step is authorization of capital to purchase the new equipment, which includes a process review to discuss the proposed equipment and how it impacts the existing process equipment from an operating procedure and safety standpoint.  The second step is a post construction review to assure that instruments have been properly installed and calibrated, that mechanical equipment has been properly i

nstalled and operates as expected, and an overall inspection of the process to assure that it is mechanically intact and ready for operation.  These procedures may be found in Section 23 of the Safety Manual.

Compliance Audits
Glo-Tex has retained the services of an outside environmental consulting firm to assist with audits of the prevention program.  Formal audits resulting in a written report occur every three years at a minimum and informal audits are conducted more frequently.  The results of these audits are then used to ensure that Glo-Tex operates in a safe and compliant manner and the past two audits are kept on site.  The audit procedure is found in Section 25 of the Safety Manual.

Incident Investigation
The RMP regulation requires a facility to begin to investigate each incident which resulted in, or could have resulted in, a "catastrophic release of a regulated substance."  A catastrophic release is one that ?presents an imminent and substantial endangerment to public health and the environment.?  

A team consisting of knowledgeable employees and, as necessary, contractors and consultants should perform the investigation.  The investigation should be started immediately.  US EPA suggests that the investigation begin within 48-hours of the incident.  The team must prepare a report, which must be retained for five years, containing the following:
?    Identification of the factors contributing to the incident,
?    A focus on the root cause as well as the initiating event,
?    Recommendations for corrective actions, and
?    A framework to assist management in taking corrective action

Though not required by the regulation, US EPA encourages facilities to investigate all accidental releases. Investigating minor accidents or near misses can help the facility identify problems that could result in major releases if not addressed.

Glo-Tex had an incident on July 21, 2006 that is subject to the regulation.  Glo-Tex enlisted the assistance of their commercial insuranc

e carrier to conduct the investigation.  Glo-Tex has a procedure entitled Incident Investigation that includes assembling an investigation team for all incidents and near misses.  These investigations are documented as appropriate for the character of the incident.  The Incident Investigation procedure may be found in Section 26 of the Safety Manual.

Employee Participation
The RMP regulation requires that management consult with the employees on the conduct and development of process hazards analyses and other required process.  This requirement requires the facility to develop a written plan to implement employee participation.  The employees must have access to PHAs and all other information required by the RMP regulation.

Safety is of utmost concern in any facility that handles hazardous chemicals.  Glo-Tex has a written Hazard Communication Plan that may be found in Section 6 of the Safety Manual.  Training of new employees and additional training and reinforcement of policies with all employees focus on hazardous materials safety, hazard communication process safety, and fire and emergency evacuation procedures as well as specific job related tasks.  Key activities such as loading and unloading of tank trucks utilize written procedures to minimize the risk of accidents.  Training centers on the Hazard Communication Plan and the basic safety rules that all employees must follow (reference Glo-Tex Safety Manual and Employee Handbook).

Employees and supervisors from the production department were included in the development of the Process Hazard Analysis.  The stated policy and procedure for employee participation may be found in Section 27 of the Safety Manual.

Hot Work Permit
The RMP Regulation requires the facility to issue a permit for hot work on or near a covered process.  The Hot Work Permit, which must be kept on file until the work is completed, should contain the following:
?    The permit must document that the fire prevention and protection requiremen

ts in 29 CFR 1910.252(a) have been implemented before the hot work begins. 
?    The permit should indicate the dates authorized for hot work.
?    The permit must identify the object on which hot work is to be performed.
Glo-Tex issues permits for all hot work performed in the plant.  A copy of Glo-Tex?s Hot Work Permit procedure is located in Section 28 of the Safety Manual.

Contractor Safety
Glo-Tex sometimes brings in outside contractors for specific tasks.  Any contractor who is performing work in the manufacturing facility is given a safety briefing based upon Glo-Tex?s Contractor Safety Program that includes the following:
?    Emergency Evacuation Plan
?    Location of Fire Extinguishers, Fire Exits, and Eye Wash/Shower Stations
?    Location of Material Safety Data Sheet
?    Location of Safety Manuals
?    Specific Hazards Workers May be Exposed To
?    Use of Personal Protective Equipment
?    Requirements of Hot-Work Permits
?    Use and Storage of any Flammable Liquids
?    Location of any Underground Utility Lines
?    Manner of Conduct
?    Other related information
Glo-Tex requires that each contractor provide documentation of training of their employees that is appropriate for the task.  Glo-Tex observes each contractor periodically and will stop the work if unsafe work practices are observed.  If unsafe work practices persist, the contractor will be dismissed.  A copy of the Contractor Policy may be found in Section 29 of the Safety Manual.

Five-Year Accident History (40 CFR 68.155(d))

On July 21, 2006, Glo-Tex experienced an over pressurization of a receiver.  The mechanical failure of the tank resulted in a metal shard flying across the production area and striking the sidewall of the vinyl acetate storage tank.  The force of the impact caused the sidewall of the tank to rupture and the static discharge ignited the vinyl acetate fumes, causing a large fire.  The fire spread to the acrylonitrile tank and other stored materials in the process area.  The polymer production area of the

plant was a complete loss.

Emergency Response Program (40 CFR 68.155(e))

Glo-Tex Emergency Response and Operating Procedures
For Level 2 and Level 3 facilities, Part 68 requires implementation of an emergency response program if the employees will respond to some releases involving regulated substances. 

US EPA recognizes that, in some cases, it is not necessary for employees to conduct response operations for releases of regulated substances.  If the employees do not respond to releases of regulated substances and if the local public responders are not capable of providing such response, the facility must take steps to ensure that effective response is available (e.g., by hiring response contractors). 
For purposes of Part 68, ?response? has the same meaning as that term has under OSHA?s HAZWOPER Standard. OSHA defines emergency response as ?a response effort by employees from outside the immediate release area or by other designated responders ... to an occurrence which results, or is likely to result, in an uncontrolled release of a hazardous substance.? 

Glo-Tex does not designate employees for response other than to address ?incidental releases of hazardous substances where:
?    the substance can be absorbed, neutralized, or otherwise controlled at the time of release by employees in the immediate release area, or by maintenance personnel or 
?    clean-up a spill that does not pose an immediate safety or health hazard.?  

These actions are not considered response under OSHA or Part 68; therefore, Glo-Tex is a ?non-responding facility? [40 CFR 68.90(b)].  A call was placed to the Spartanburg County Emergency Preparedness office (864 595-5365) and the following information was confirmed.  In Spartanburg County, industrial facilities are effectively included in the Community Emergency Operations Plan coordinated through the Emergency Preparedness office.  Glo-Tex will be included in the next revision of the EOP and will be located in Group ESF-100.  

The facili

ties are instructed to contact the jurisdictional fire department for emergency response in the event of a chemical emergency.  The fire chief has authority to call out the hazardous materials response team as he deems appropriate to the emergency conditions.  The facilities are required to provide SARA 312 information and Glo-Tex has had several training sessions with the local fire department to assure that their personnel are familiar with the facility.  Glo-Tex plans to continue periodic training with the fire department as necessary to assure that an appropriate emergency response will be made.

For ?non-responding facilities?, EPA has adopted a policy similar to OSHA in its Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (HAZWOPER) [29 CFR 1910.120].  This allows these facilities to develop an emergency action plan to ensure employee safety, rather than a full-fledged emergency response plan provided that they coordinate with local response agencies to ensure that they will be prepared to respond to an emergency at the facility.

 
Coordination with local responders also entails the following:
?    If the facility has a covered process with a regulated toxic substance, it must be included in the community emergency response plan prepared under EPCRA regarding a response to a potential release.
?    If the facility has a covered process with a regulated flammable, it must ensure that the local fire department is capable of responding to a potential release and aware of its responsibility to do so.

To document the requirements, the facility should have a record of: 
?    The emergency contact (i.e., name or organization and number) that would be called for a toxic or flammable release, and
?    The organization(s) that would assist with response procedures.

Glo-Tex operates in a manner that attempts to minimize hazards associated with the handling of chemicals.  Glo-Tex has several mechanisms in place for addressing a release of a regulated hazardous substance.  These i

nclude the following:
?    A Emergency Action Plan that documents the emergency contacts 
?    An employee safety manual
?    Procedures for unloading tank trucks
?    A severe weather plan

Emergency Action Plan
The Emergency Action Plan that was developed in conjunction with the Process Hazard Analysis for the Polymer Manufacturing Process contains detailed information relating to materials stored on site, potential failures of equipment, and methods for containing or cleaning up lost materials.  Manufacturing activities are discussed and chemicals are grouped with regard to their physical properties.  Emergency contacts are identified and a notification procedure is detailed.
?    All plant-operating personnel are required to notify their immediate supervisor in the event of an emergency.
?    The supervisor will then contact the plant EHS Manager (EHS).
?    The EHS Manager or Plant Management will contact the appropriate local response organizations and, as necessary, state and federal agencies.

A call list designating these contacts is provided in the Emergency Action Plan.  A copy of the Emergency Action Plan is located in Section 14 of the Safety Manual.

Tank Truck Unloading
Glo-Tex regularly receives shipments of chemicals in tank trucks and transfers these materials into bulk storage tanks located in the raw material tank farms with secondary containment.  The tank trucks are parked in secondary containment areas located at the tank farm and unloaded by trained personnel.  Glo-Tex has a documented procedure for these operators to follow.  This procedure is located on the Glo-Tex network and is available to employees through their supervisor.

Severe Weather Plan
In the event of severe weather, Glo-Tex is dedicated to protecting its employees and the surrounding community.  Procedures have been set up to warn plant employees and shut down key operations in order to minimize material loss in the event of a weather related failure.  The emergency action plan is located in Secti

on 14 of the Glo-Tex Safety Manual.

Planned Change to Improve Safety (40 CFR 68.155(f))
After the fire on July 21, 2006, Glo-Tex retained a number of local consultants to assist with the reconstruction of the facility.  Among those consultants were process specialists, process control specialists, and environmental, safety and health specialists.  The process specialists assisted with the specification and installation of replacement equipment including specifications for the relief device sizing and equipment arrangement to reduce the potential for future incidents.  Process control specialists assisted with the specification and installation of process control computers, process instrumentation, and writing process control code to provide alarms and interlocks.  The environmental, safety and health specialists assisted with the process hazard analysis and preparation of the various policies and procedures for such things as spill control and management of change.  Facility personnel have instituted a more formal employee participation program, incident investigation, new asset acquisition, new asset installation, and standard operating instructions for the manufacturing process.
